Testing Bioremeditation!
properties.description: Wishard of Oz (finally home& catching up) posted a photo: The theme of this year's ATEEC Fellows Institute is bioremediation of oil. Evidently there are millions of little buggers out there that thrive off of oil, and they are consuming by the barrel out in the Gulf of Mexico thanks to BP's oil buffet for them. Here we are doing a lab to measure how many of the little buggers are really out in the local environment here in Minnesota. BTW- That real cude oil in the syringe here.

properties.title: Day 110- Bubbles with Duckie!
properties.description: Wishard of Oz (finally home& catching up) posted a photo: April 20, 110/365 (1206/1461)- Finished up the "regular" state-standardized testing this morning, so the "Queen of Testing" gave all of us that went above and beyond a rubber ducky with bubbles in it. She really is in charge of our guidance department, known as the ducks because they always look so calm on the surface but paddling like hell underneath. Today marks two events that forever changed the lives of teachers, and the lives of us coastal dwellers on the Gulf of Mexico. It's the 12th anniversary of the Columbine shootings which certainly changed how schools handle bullying and security issues. It's also the first anniversary of the Deep Horizon/BP oil fiasco, which has forever changed the lives of those that depend on the Gulf for a living. RIP+ to the 11 drillers just doing their job for BP that died on the rig and the 12 students & 1 teacher that died at the hands of two emotionally deranged students with weapons in school.

properties.title: 1 year ago today.........
properties.description: DirtyJerz Photography posted a photo:

properties.title: Peninsula Washing Away
properties.description: NWFblogs posted a photo: Marsh grasses killed by BP oil have left a peninsula in Louisiana's Bay Jimmy at the mercy of the tides, with large gaps opening. Mylar flags and propane cannons are meant to keep birds from nesting in the oiled marsh, but we saw a pelican fishing nearby.

properties.title: Crews Scrape Oiled Marshes
properties.description: NWFblogs posted a photo: Crews scrape contaminated sediment out of oiled marshes in Louisiana's Bay Jimmy - an effort that may be doing more harm than good

properties.title: Oiled Marshes in Louisiana's Bay Jimmy
properties.description: NWFblogs posted a photo: One year after the BP oil gusher began, an inch-thick layer of oil still contaminates many Louisiana wetlands

properties.title: Observing Oiled Marsh Scraping
properties.description: NWFblogs posted a photo: National Wildlife Federation staff and an NBC News crew observe efforts to scrape contaminated sediment out of oiled marshes in Louisiana's Bay Jimmy

properties.title: Best french bread on the coast
properties.description: /\ \/\/ /\ posted a photo: Down at the end of Division Street on Oak St. is the Le Bakery which serves Vietnamese style sandwiches, pastry, and bread....now you just need some COREXIT-free baby crabs. Seewww.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/27/gulf-oil-spill-chemical...

properties.title: Sadness
properties.description: RonWooten posted a photo: A young biologist kneels beside a stranded young female bottlenose dolphin. This dolphin had died a day or two before, hopefully at sea but likely stranded on the beach. With no water to support their weight, many of these animals die from asphyxiation. Marine mammals tend to strand after illness or injury, and should never be pushed back out. Gulf Coast states all have local marine mammal stranding networks that will help rescue live animals or pick up dead animals in efforts to determine a cause of death-very important information, especially after the oil spill.

properties.description: Wishard of Oz (finally home& catching up) posted a photo: A rather nameless shrimp boat seen up one of the bayous in Southport; looks like some of their off time from the BP oil disaster gave them time to work on new gunwales that still weren't painted. The whole scene just looked like it needed to be black & white.
